newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Aug 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Aug 11.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Monday:
* President Clinton will exercise his line-item veto authority on Monday and kill some new items from the recently signed balanced-budget and tax-cut legislation.
* American drivers are consuming record quantities of gasoline this year.
* Privacy advocates plan to challenge the FBI's plan for high-technology wire-tapping.
* Officials at United Parcel Service stepped up their calls for President Clinton to intervene in its strike with the Teamsters union.
* The first fruits of a new policy by the World Bank and IMF to try and eliminate corruption in poor nations is starting to become visible.
* EDS shares fell Friday when second-quarter results came in lower-than-expected.
* HarperCollins is now faced with the task of convincing agents and authors of its committment to the future.
* Yamaichi Securities said that its chairman, president and five vice president were expected to resign over the firm's suspected payoff to a racketeer.
* The Energy Department is preparing to borrow space in a civilian power plant to make tritium for nuclear weapons.
* It is unclear whether Apple Computer will continue to license the Macintosh operating system to makers of lower-priced Mac clones.
* General Mills is setting up a Betty Crocker Web site.
